channel.title: Design engineering services by service design and business architecture
channel.description: Design engineering services by service design and business architecture

item.title: Practical Service Design - guides, resources, and community
item.description:
Practical Service Design - guides, resources, and community

Our world is now made of services. We need new tools to think across this space, to not only create memorable and valuable experiences for our customers, but also empower our organizations to change the way we do business for the better.

item.title: Video: What is service design?
item.description:
Video: What is service design?

Design Methods Step 1: Discover Step one in a four-part guide for anyone who wants to understand the methods designers use and try them out for themselves. Discover - keep your perspectives wide, allowing for a broad range of ideas and influences.

item.title: Francisco Guzman // On the Other Side of the Line: Designing with Shoppers in Mind // Service Experience Conference 2015
item.description:
Francisco Guzman // On the Other Side of the Line: Designing with Shoppers in Mind // Service Experience Conference 2015

With Instacart, customers can get groceries delivered from their favorite local stores in as little as an hour. Behind the scenes, Instacart is powered by an amazing...

item.title: Katie Koch // Putting Service Design Into Practice // Service Experience Conference 2015
item.description:
Katie Koch // Putting Service Design Into Practice // Service Experience Conference 2015

How do you practice service design when you don't have the budget, time, or scope to impact the entire service? On my design team at American Express we've...

item.title: IBM Design: design in motion
item.description:
IBM Design: design in motion

Design is a constant exploration of creation and destruction; of cacophony and utter loneliness. We need space and spaces. Where we argue, play, rest, think. Welcome to IBM Design Studios.

item.title: Better User Experience With Storytelling - Part 2 - Smashing Magazine
item.description:
Better User Experience With Storytelling - Part 2 - Smashing Magazine

In the first part of this Better User Experience With Storytelling series, we explored some of the basic structures and story patterns found in myths and religions. We saw how these patterns continued into modern stories such as The Matrix and Star Wars.

item.title: Service Design Research
item.description:
Service Design Research

From the article: "Recent research projects have looked for social innovations, i.e., people creating solutions outside the mainstream patterns of production and consumption. An analysis of these innovations indicates the emergence of a particular kind of service configurationdefined here as relational serviceswhich requires intensive interpersonal relations to operate.

item.title: Lessons from 5 years of Lean UX - InVision Blog
item.description:
Lessons from 5 years of Lean UX - InVision Blog

Since the idea first percolated in 2010 through to its current state as a permanent hashtag on Twitter, Lean UX changed the way we look at designing products-including how we work with our colleagues in product management, software engineering, marketing, and executive leadership.

item.title: UX design tips for your app, part 2 - InVision Blog
item.description:
UX design tips for your app, part 2 - InVision Blog

Let's continue talking about the user experience in the context of apps. Tips such as making the UX adapt to the user, network-awareness, onboarding, and other concepts related to the user experience were covered in the first segment of this article series. Here are a few other UX tips to consider.

item.title: The value of consistent design - InVision Blog
item.description:
The value of consistent design - InVision Blog

To many designers, consistency doesn't scream sexy. But to anyone with an understanding of user experience, there couldn't be a bigger turn on. We should design with this in mind. Anyone who tells you their product was a success because of the intuitive design they created is overselling their skills.
